scenes.plot_segment: Meredith Grey delivers a contemplative voiceover about intimacy, describing it as something people crave yet fear, difficult to live with and impossible to live without. She connects intimacy to life’s “three Rs”: relatives, romance, and roommates. As the narration unfolds, Meredith, Izzie Stevens, and George O’Malley navigate the awkwardness of their shared living situation early in the morning. George is visibly uncomfortable as Meredith and Izzie walk around the house in their underwear, and he protests when asked to buy tampons, insisting that he doesn’t buy “girl products.” Izzie teases George, telling him to get used to seeing her in her underwear, while Cristina Yang jokes about the situation. The roommates briefly discuss setting house rules, and George’s crush on one of the women is hinted at, though he denies it when confronted. The scene establishes the complexities and discomforts of their new living arrangement, setting a thematic tone about the challenges of personal boundaries and connection.

In the early morning at Meredith Grey’s house, George O’Malley becomes visibly uncomfortable as Meredith and Izzie Stevens walk around the shared bathroom in their underwear while getting ready for work. Izzie, unfazed, teases George about his discomfort and tells him to get used to seeing his roommates in their underwear. Meredith casually asks George to pick up tampons for her, prompting George to protest that he doesn’t buy “girl products” and doesn’t want to see his roommates undressed. Cristina Yang enters and jokes about the situation, further embarrassing George. The roommates bicker about boundaries and household responsibilities, with Izzie and Cristina pushing George to accept the realities of living with women. The exchange highlights the awkwardness of their new living arrangement and George’s underlying crush, which he awkwardly denies when confronted.

At Seattle Grace Hospital in the early morning, Dr. Miranda Bailey firmly instructs Meredith Grey and George O’Malley on the importance of pre-rounds. She emphasizes that they must be polite and make patients feel comfortable so they’ll share valuable information, which the interns are expected to relay to the attendings. Bailey warns that if they make her look bad in front of the attendings, she will make their lives difficult. She insists that pre-rounds must be completed by 5:30 a.m., setting a strict tone for the day and making it clear she expects nothing less than excellence from her interns.

In the hospital corridor, Alex Karev greets Izzie Stevens with the nickname “Dr. Model,” mocking her past as a lingerie model and making crude remarks about her tattoos. Izzie fires back with sarcastic banter, defending herself and brushing off Alex’s teasing. Cristina Yang joins them, frustrated about her previous day’s patient assignments and determined to secure a better surgical case. Cristina and Alex discuss the importance of arriving early to impress Dr. Preston Burke, with Cristina emphasizing her ambition. When Alex insinuates that Cristina might be involved with an attending, Cristina pointedly denies any such relationship, making it clear she’s focused solely on her surgical career. The group’s conversation is laced with competitive energy and underlying tension as they prepare for the day’s assignments.

Cristina Yang quietly enters the hospital room of Nurse Elizabeth Fallon, a respected former scrub nurse now hospitalized with advanced pancreatic cancer. Cristina tries to wake Fallon gently, but Fallon immediately recognizes Cristina’s eagerness and correctly guesses that she’s there early to review her chart and impress Dr. Preston Burke in hopes of assisting on Fallon’s surgery. Fallon, sharp and perceptive despite her illness, asserts her authority by insisting Cristina address her as “Nurse Fallon” and calls Cristina by her first name, establishing boundaries and demonstrating her deep understanding of hospital hierarchy and politics.

Izzie Stevens enters Mr. Humphrey’s hospital room to perform a pre-biopsy exam, but he immediately recognizes her from a lingerie modeling ad and becomes visibly uncomfortable. Embarrassed and upset, Mr. Humphrey refuses to let Izzie touch him or proceed with the examination, insisting that he wants a different doctor. Despite Izzie’s attempts to reassure him of her professionalism, he adamantly demands she leave, leaving Izzie frustrated and feeling objectified as she exits the room.

In the interns’ shared house early in the morning, Meredith Grey, Izzie Stevens, and George O’Malley navigate the awkwardness of living together. George is visibly uncomfortable as Izzie and Meredith walk around in their underwear, and he protests when Izzie asks him to buy tampons, insisting that he shouldn’t have to purchase “girl products.” Izzie teases George, telling him to get used to seeing her in her underwear, while Meredith tries to mediate. The roommates debate setting house rules about nudity and boundaries, and Izzie jokes about George having a crush on one of them, which he denies. Their conversation is abruptly interrupted by a hospital page summoning O’Malley, Grey, and Alex Karev to respond to a trauma case.

Meredith Grey, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev respond to a trauma case in the emergency bay as Jorge Cruz arrives conscious but blind, with seven nails embedded in his skull after accidentally shooting himself with a nail gun while falling down stairs. As they assess his injuries, Jorge’s wife, Sona, arrives and scolds him for his carelessness, expressing both worry and frustration. The team discusses the complexity and rarity of his injuries, noting the risk to his vision and brain function. With the CT scanner out of service, Dr. Derek Shepherd and Dr. Preston Burke debate the safest imaging options and agree to proceed with X-rays and a C-Arm to guide their next steps. The interns work quickly to stabilize Jorge, preparing him for surgery while Sona anxiously waits nearby.

Cristina Yang presents Nurse Elizabeth Fallon’s case to Dr. Preston Burke, emphasizing Fallon’s extensive experience as a scrub nurse and her recent diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. Burke acknowledges Cristina’s ambition and notes her eagerness to assist in the Whipple procedure. He reveals he had intended to assign Fallon’s case to Meredith Grey, given Fallon’s long history working with Ellis Grey, Meredith’s mother, hoping it might foster a connection. Cristina is surprised, and Fallon clarifies that despite working with Ellis for 18 years, she never actually met Meredith. As they discuss the case, Dr. Bailey enters and mentions that Meredith is currently assisting Dr. Derek Shepherd and Dr. Burke on the nail gun trauma case, confirming Meredith’s unavailability for Fallon’s surgery.

Dr. Preston Burke instructs Meredith Grey to order additional tests for Nurse Elizabeth Fallon, including blood work, an MRI, an enema, and a biopsy, to further investigate her worsening condition. He emphasizes that Meredith is responsible for Fallon’s care, noting Fallon’s long-standing reputation as a respected scrub nurse and her close professional history with Meredith’s mother, Ellis Grey. Meredith listens attentively, aware of the significance of being assigned to a patient who is considered an institution at the hospital.

Meredith Grey interviews Jorge Cruz, who is conscious but temporarily blind after accidentally shooting seven nails into his head with a nail gun. Meredith gently asks Jorge about his recent health, focusing on his headaches and episodes of lightheadedness. Sona Cruz, his wife, arrives in the trauma bay, visibly upset and scolding Jorge for his carelessness. As Meredith continues her assessment, Sona provides additional medical history, explaining that Jorge has been experiencing worsening headaches and dizziness over the past few weeks. Meredith listens carefully, gathering details that may be relevant to Jorge’s current condition and the upcoming surgical decisions.

In the kitchen early in the morning, George O’Malley talks with Alex Karev about his discomfort living with Meredith Grey and Izzie Stevens, who frequently walk around their shared house in their underwear. Alex teases George, asking if it’s like living in a sorority and whether he finds it exciting. George awkwardly insists that it’s not sexual and compares the situation to living with sisters, though his embarrassment and hesitation suggest he’s conflicted about his feelings. Alex continues to prod, hinting at George’s crush on one of the women, but George denies it, growing increasingly flustered as the conversation exposes his discomfort with the lack of boundaries in their living arrangement.

Izzie Stevens enters Mr. Humphrey’s room to assist with his prostate biopsy, but Mr. Humphrey recognizes her from a lingerie advertisement and pointedly demands that she leave, refusing to let her participate in his care. Dr. Bailey steps in to reassure Mr. Humphrey and calmly prepares to begin the procedure, while Izzie, visibly frustrated and embarrassed, exits the room.

Meredith Grey interviews Sona Cruz about her husband Jorge’s symptoms following his nail gun accident. Meredith asks about Jorge’s recent health, and Sona explains that Jorge has been experiencing dizziness and disorientation for the past couple of months, not just since the accident. Meredith listens carefully, taking notes as Sona describes how Jorge has seemed confused and forgetful at home, sometimes getting lost or struggling to remember things. Sona expresses concern that these symptoms have gradually worsened, and she worries that something more serious may be wrong with Jorge beyond the trauma from the accident. Meredith reassures Sona that the team will do everything they can to help, and she prepares to relay this information to Dr. Bailey and the surgical team as they consider Jorge’s treatment options.

Izzie Stevens vents to fellow intern George O’Malley about her frustration with Mr. Humphrey, a patient who refuses to let her treat him after recognizing her from a lingerie magazine ad. George tries to reassure her, but Izzie feels humiliated and questions whether she’ll ever be seen as a serious doctor. Dr. Miranda Bailey interrupts, firmly instructing Izzie to continue with Mr. Humphrey’s case and making it clear that if the biopsy is positive, she expects Izzie to be present in surgery regardless of the patient’s objections. Izzie reluctantly agrees, determined to prove herself despite the setback.

Meredith Grey and George O’Malley discuss Jorge Cruz’s symptoms and the circumstances of his accident, considering possible causes for his sudden loss of consciousness that led to him shooting seven nails into his head with a nail gun. They debate whether Jorge may have an underlying condition, such as a brain tumor, that could have caused him to faint. Dr. Miranda Bailey joins the conversation, emphasizing the need to stabilize Jorge and prioritize his immediate surgical needs. The team decides to focus on safely removing the nails and getting Jorge through surgery before pursuing further diagnostic tests to determine the root cause of his collapse.

In the OR, Dr. Derek Shepherd leads the surgical team as they prepare to remove the seven nails embedded in Jorge Cruz’s skull. Cristina Yang and Alex Karev observe the X-rays and discuss the complexity of the case, with Cristina expressing her desire to assist on Nurse Fallon’s Whipple procedure instead. Dr. Preston Burke and Dr. Shepherd debate the safest extraction method, given the lack of a CT scan, ultimately relying on X-rays and the C-Arm for guidance. Meredith Grey assists, carefully monitoring Jorge’s neurological status as the team meticulously plans the delicate extraction to avoid further damage, especially to the optic nerve. The atmosphere is tense as the surgeons scrub in, aware of the high stakes and the rarity of the injury.

Cristina Yang is questioned by Dr. Preston Burke about Nurse Elizabeth Fallon’s abnormal blood work and is instructed to take Fallon for an MRI. Cristina, eager to participate in the Whipple procedure for Fallon’s pancreatic cancer, asks Burke if she can scrub in on the surgery. Burke, aware of Cristina’s ambition, tells her to focus on caring for Fallon overnight instead. During their interaction, Fallon recognizes Cristina’s drive and calls her out for angling to get into surgery, insisting on being addressed as “Nurse Fallon” and demonstrating her deep knowledge of hospital dynamics. Burke ultimately assigns Meredith Grey to the Whipple case due to Fallon’s long history with Meredith’s mother, Ellis Grey, leaving Cristina frustrated but determined to prove herself.

Meredith sits with her mother, Ellis Grey, in the nursing home, gently showing her old family photographs in an attempt to spark recognition. Ellis, confused and disoriented due to her early-onset Alzheimer’s, fails to recognize herself, her husband Thatcher Grey, or young Meredith in the pictures. Meredith quietly tries to prompt memories, but Ellis grows agitated and distant, underscoring the emotional gap between them and Meredith’s struggle to connect with the mother she is slowly losing.

Meredith visits Ellis Grey at the nursing home and mentions that she saw Nurse Elizabeth Fallon at the hospital. Ellis’s face lights up with recognition, recalling Liz fondly from their years working together. She asks Meredith how Liz is doing, and Meredith gently explains that Nurse Fallon is very sick. Ellis reminisces about Liz’s skill as a scrub nurse, and Meredith confirms that she was one of the best, sharing a brief moment of connection with her mother despite Ellis’s confusion.

George O’Malley, Meredith Grey, and Izzie Stevens bicker in their shared kitchen early in the morning. Meredith and Izzie tease George for being squeamish about buying tampons, insisting that living with women means accepting their needs. Izzie, still in her underwear, tells George to get used to seeing them in various states of undress. George protests, embarrassed and frustrated, insisting that buying “girl products” isn’t something he should have to do. Meredith and Izzie push back, joking that he needs to adapt if he wants to live with them. The exchange ends with George exclaiming that he is not their sister, highlighting his discomfort with the realities of cohabiting with two women.

The following morning, Jorge Cruz wakes up in his hospital bed with Meredith Grey and Sona Cruz at his side. When Sona enters the room wearing a red dress, Jorge is able to recognize the color, indicating that some of his vision has returned after the surgery to remove the nails from his head. Meredith and Sona exchange relieved smiles, pleased with Jorge’s progress and hopeful about his recovery.

Cristina Yang is sternly corrected by Dr. Preston Burke after she abruptly wakes Nurse Elizabeth Fallon, a former scrub nurse now hospitalized with pancreatic cancer. Burke tells Cristina that her impatience and lack of bedside manner are unacceptable, emphasizing that being a surgeon means handling difficult situations without expecting sympathy. He reminds her that compassion for patients is essential, even when ambition and surgical opportunities are at stake.

In the locker room, Izzie Stevens confronts Alex Karev and George O’Malley after enduring repeated jokes about her modeling past and the nickname “Dr. Model.” Frustrated by their objectification and dismissive attitudes, Izzie strips down to her underwear, revealing her tattoos, and defiantly challenges them to look at her if they’re so interested. She asserts her competence as a doctor, reminding them that her modeling career paid for her medical school tuition and left her debt-free, unlike many of her peers. Izzie demands respect for her skills and hard work, making it clear that her past does not define her abilities as a surgeon.

Meredith Grey and Sona Cruz sit together at Jorge Cruz’s bedside, discussing Jorge’s daily habits, including his usual breakfast routine. Sona expresses concern about Jorge’s condition and asks if he will be able to eat normally again. Meredith gently explains that Jorge needs an MRI to check for any residual bleeding in his brain before they can proceed, reassuring Sona that the medical team is doing everything possible to ensure Jorge’s safety. Sona, anxious but hopeful, thanks Meredith for her care and support.

Izzie Stevens confronts Mr. Humphrey in his hospital room after he refuses to let her participate in his care. Mr. Humphrey admits he recognized Izzie from her lingerie modeling photo and feels embarrassed and emasculated at the thought of her seeing him vulnerable during his prostate surgery. Izzie firmly asserts her professionalism, explaining that her past as a model does not affect her abilities as a doctor. She insists that he allow her to do her job, emphasizing that his care and outcome are her top priorities, and challenges him to see her as his physician rather than an object.

Cristina Yang and Dr. Preston Burke discuss Nurse Elizabeth Fallon’s worsening condition in the hospital hallway. Cristina, eager to assist in a major surgery, argues that Fallon’s deteriorating labs and symptoms warrant moving forward with a Whipple procedure for her pancreatic cancer. Burke, however, remains cautious and noncommittal, insisting they wait to review Fallon’s biopsy results and overnight lab work before making any surgical decisions. Cristina’s frustration is evident as she pushes for immediate action, but Burke emphasizes the need for a thorough assessment, leaving the plan unresolved.

Meredith Grey and Dr. Derek Shepherd review Jorge Cruz’s MRI scans and discover a tumor located in his hypothalamus. As George O’Malley observes, Meredith and Derek discuss the two available treatment options with Jorge and his wife, Sona. Surgical removal of the tumor could potentially extend Jorge’s life by five to ten years but carries significant risks, including possible memory loss and changes to his personality due to the tumor’s location. Alternatively, focused radiation is less invasive and safer but would likely only give Jorge an additional three to five years. Sona struggles with the emotional weight of the decision, fearing the possibility of losing the man she loves even if he survives the surgery. Meredith gently explains the implications of each option, emphasizing the difficult balance between quality and quantity of life, while Sona insists she will support whatever choice Jorge makes, even if it means caring for a husband who may no longer remember her.

Meredith Grey returns to Nurse Elizabeth Fallon’s hospital room to deliver difficult news. She gently informs Fallon that Ellis Grey, her former colleague and renowned surgeon, has been diagnosed with early-onset Alzheimer’s disease. Fallon is visibly shocked and saddened, recalling Ellis’s unwavering dedication to the hospital and expressing disbelief that someone so formidable could be facing such a decline. Meredith explains that Ellis is now living in a nursing home and insists that Ellis wants her diagnosis kept confidential. Fallon promises to respect Ellis’s wishes, and the two women share a moment of understanding, bonded by their connection to Ellis and the weight of the secret.

In the doctors’ lounge, Dr. Miranda Bailey leads a tense discussion with Dr. Preston Burke and several interns about Nurse Elizabeth Fallon’s rapidly declining condition. Bailey asserts that every possible intervention should be considered for Fallon, emphasizing her years of service to the hospital. Burke, however, questions the ethics of aggressive treatment, pointing out Fallon’s DNR order and deteriorating labs. Meredith Grey advocates for pursuing the Whipple procedure, arguing that Fallon deserves a chance, while Cristina Yang listens intently, aware of Fallon’s wishes and her connection to Ellis Grey. The conversation highlights the conflict between respecting a patient’s autonomy and the instinct to fight for every life, with the doctors divided over whether to honor Fallon’s desire for comfort or push for surgery despite the risks.

Izzie Stevens and Cristina Yang are in the locker room discussing the fallout from Izzie’s modeling past. Cristina jokes about Izzie’s lingerie ads, while Izzie explains that her appearance in those photos is the result of professional makeup, lighting, and retouching, not reality. As Izzie vents her frustration about being objectified and not taken seriously as a doctor, the other interns—George O’Malley and Alex Karev—join in, teasing Izzie about her looks and calling her “Dr. Model.” Izzie stands her ground, insisting that she worked hard to become a doctor and that her modeling career paid for her medical school, but she wants to be recognized for her skills, not her appearance. The group’s banter continues, with Cristina and the others jokingly claiming to “hate” Izzie for her looks, but the underlying tension about respect and professionalism remains.

Izzie Stevens is paged by Dr. Miranda Bailey, who firmly reminds her that Mr. Humphrey’s refusal to let Izzie participate in his care—due to recognizing her from a lingerie modeling ad—does not excuse her from her responsibilities as a surgical intern. Bailey insists that Izzie continue to perform her duties regardless of the patient’s discomfort or her own frustration about being objectified and called “Dr. Model” by both patients and colleagues. Izzie, visibly upset by the ongoing references to her modeling past, struggles to maintain her professionalism as she prepares for Mr. Humphrey’s prostatectomy, determined to prove her competence as a doctor despite the disrespect she faces.

Dr. Derek Shepherd and Dr. Preston Burke meet with Jorge Cruz and his wife, Sona, to explain the options for treating Jorge’s brain tumor: surgical removal, which carries a high risk of damaging his memory and personality, or radiation, which is less invasive but offers fewer years of survival. Sona is visibly distressed, torn between wanting more time with Jorge and fearing the loss of the man she loves if his personality is altered. Meredith Grey is present and tries to offer comfort, but Sona insists that the final decision must be Jorge’s, emphasizing her commitment to supporting his wishes even if it means living with a husband who may not remember her.

Cristina Yang realizes that the promised Whipple procedure for Nurse Elizabeth Fallon was never actually intended, understanding that she has been subjected to a hazing ritual by the other doctors. As this realization dawns on her, Nurse Fallon’s condition suddenly deteriorates. Cristina, Meredith Grey, and the other interns rush to her bedside and attempt to resuscitate her, but Dr. Miranda Bailey intervenes, reminding them that Fallon is DNR (do not resuscitate). Despite their emotional struggle, the interns are ordered to stop their efforts and let Nurse Fallon pass away, with Meredith quietly calling the time of death.

In the operating room, Izzie Stevens and Dr. Miranda Bailey advocate for a nerve-sparing approach during Mr. Humphrey’s prostatectomy, emphasizing the importance of preserving his sexual function and overall quality of life. Dr. Victor, the attending surgeon, is initially dismissive and prefers the standard, less complex procedure, but Izzie stands her ground, referencing both medical evidence and the patient’s wishes. Bailey supports Izzie’s argument, reinforcing the ethical responsibility to consider the patient’s future well-being. After a tense exchange, Dr. Victor reluctantly agrees to attempt the more challenging nerve-sparing surgery, acknowledging the interns’ commitment to patient-centered care.

Cristina Yang and Meredith Grey sit together after a long shift, quietly processing the emotional weight of losing Nurse Fallon. Cristina admits how hard it is to lose patients, especially someone as respected as Fallon, and questions how they’re supposed to handle the grief while maintaining professional boundaries. Meredith reflects on the blurred lines between their personal and professional lives, acknowledging how difficult it is to know when boundaries have been crossed, especially when intimacy with patients and colleagues is both necessary and risky. Their conversation underscores the struggle to define their own rules for coping and connection in the high-pressure world of medicine.

Meredith calls the time of death for Nurse Elizabeth Fallon, honoring her DNR wishes as Cristina Yang and Dr. Preston Burke look on. Meredith’s voiceover reflects on the absence of a rule book for intimacy and the difficulty of recognizing personal boundaries. The interns return home after their exhausting shift; Izzie Stevens and Cristina discuss the challenges they face as women in medicine, while George O’Malley awkwardly navigates the house rules, still uncomfortable about buying tampons and sharing space with his female roommates. The group debates toothbrush etiquette and other living arrangements, their banter revealing both lingering tensions and growing camaraderie. As they say good night, Meredith concludes in voiceover that perhaps the rules of intimacy must be defined individually, each person setting their own boundaries as they learn to live together.
